I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  proposed 
administration of a grant to be provided by the Government of Australia to the Kingdom of 
Cambodia for the Rural Energy Project.1  
 
2.  The United Nations General Assembly has recognized the importance of energy access 
to achieve the Millennium Development Goals and has designated 2012 the International Year 
of Sustainable Energy for All. The project addresses both power and non-power energy supply 
in rural Cambodia through (i) electrifying up to 8,000 households in Svay Rieng province by 
extending  the  22  kilovolt  (kV)  medium-voltage  sub-transmission  line  and  the  low-voltage 
distribution network, and installing meters;2 (ii) promoting the use of up to 90,000 improved 
cookstoves with higher efficiency in rural areas of Kampong Cham province; and (iii) developing 
the  capacity  of  the  Electricity  Authority  of  Cambodia  (EAC),  which  is  the  regulatory  body 
overseeing the power sector.  
 
3.  The project was initially conceived to be implemented by the World Bank. However, as 
the World Bank suspended new lending to Cambodia in August 2011, the governments of 
Australia and Cambodia requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB), with a proven track 
record in Cambodia’s energy sector, to implement the project, which will help increase the 
electrification ratio and contribute to poverty reduction. 
 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
4.  Sector overview. Devastated by civil war and conflict, Cambodia has experienced years 
of civil strife and power shortages. Power infrastructures remain underdeveloped, but the recent 
development of the high-voltage (230 kV and 115 kV) transmission and medium-voltage sub-
transmission lines has improved the reliability of power supply. Development partners (including 
ADB) have provided assistance for grid extension to Electricité du Cambodge (EDC), the state-
owned vertically integrated power utility, which owns and operates most of the generation and 
transmission facilities as well as the distribution networks in urban areas.  
 
5.  Although the total domestic installed capacity increased from 360 megawatts (MW) to 
553 MW owing to the commissioning of Kamchay hydropower plant in 2011, the medium-term 
power supply strategy continues to be to import electricity from neighboring countries (including 
Thailand and Viet Nam) to provide affordable electricity services and to facilitate grid extension.  
 
6.  Challenges:  Power.  Cambodia’s  electrification  rate  of  26%  is  extremely  low  in 
Southeast Asia, compared with 96% in Viet Nam and 70% in the Lao People’s Democratic 
Republic.3 At  153  kilowatt-hours  (kWh)  per  capita,  Cambodia  also  has  one  of  the  lowest 
electricity consumptions in the region. While the electrification rate in urban areas is nearly 90%, 
it is merely 11% in rural areas. More than 11 million people rely on charged automobile batteries 
for electricity, and kerosene and candles for lighting.  
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The project is designed to connect 13,000 households. This target is expected to be achieved only in 2016 since 
many households will not connect immediately because of lack of funds to pay the initial connection fees.

7.  In  contrast,  its  electricity  tariffs  are  one  of  the  highest  in  the  world  because  its 
fragmented grids are mostly supplied by diesel power generators using expensive imported fuel. 
EDC’s tariff for residential consumers is $0.17/kWh in Phnom Penh and typically higher in other 
towns, depending on the source of electricity and fuel transportation costs. Areas not supplied 
by EDC are serviced by rural electricity enterprises (REEs), which are private service providers 
licensed by EAC to distribute electricity either (i) purchased from EDC in bulk (retail tariff of 
$0.28–$0.30/kWh), or (ii) generated by its own generators (retail tariff of $0.65–$0.90/kWh). 
 
8.  Non-power. In Cambodia, 93% of the population relies on combustion of traditional 
biomass for cooking. Where traditional biomass is used, it is reported that women and children 
are exposed to air pollution levels in the form of particulates that can reach 20 times the 
maximum recommended levels, and is said to attribute to 600,000 premature deaths annually in 
Asia and the Pacific (footnote 3). A survey in Cambodia found that the incidence of symptoms of 
acute respiratory diseases among children under the age of five was four times higher in 
households using firewood as cooking fuel than those using modern fuel.4 The same data show 
that the incidence among adult women is much higher than men in the same age group. The 
use of traditional biomass for cooking also degrades the local environment through cutting of 
trees, and adds to greenhouse gas emissions. 
 
9.  Government’s strategy: Power. The electrification targets set by the government are 
(i) a 100% village electrification rate by 2020, and (ii) a household electrification rate of at least 
70% by 2030. The Strategy and Plan for Development of Rural Electrification in the Kingdom of 
Cambodia states that these targets will be attained mainly by grid extension, and partly by the 
development of mini-grids and stand-alone systems. It is estimated that an investment in excess 
of $1 billion is needed to reach these targets, of which $890 million will be for grid extension.5 
 
10.  While the primary responsibility for rural electrification lies with EDC, the REEs continue 
to play a major role in supplying the rural areas. Thus, the strategy also calls for encouraging 
the  approximately  250  existing  REEs  to  expand  their  distribution  networks.  The  Rural 
Electrification  Fund,  an  independent  fund  established  under  a  World  Bank  project,  has 
supported the REEs to expand their distribution networks. After the closing of the World Bank 
project in January 2012, the fund was incorporated under EDC in August 2012. Strengthening of 
the fund and EAC, which grants licenses and supervises the REEs, is deemed critical for 
attaining the rural electrification targets. 
 
11.  Non-power. The Ministry of Industry, Mines and Energy (MIME) is preparing the rural 
energy strategy and implementation plan, including the sustainable use of charcoal and the 
promotion of improved cookstoves. The Neang Kongrey Stove (NKS) is a key initiative since 
these improved cookstoves are tested to be 20% more efficient than traditional ones that are 
widely used. The NKS is expected to reduce pressure on household energy expenditure, the 
natural forest, and drudgery of women and children who traditionally collect firewood. It is also 
reported that each unit will reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 0.10–0.18 tons per year. 
 
12.  ADB sector experience. ADB has made important contributions to the power sector 
through a series of investments and technical assistance projects.6 ADB’s country assistance

program evaluation for Cambodia, 1998–2008 assessed the energy sector assistance strategy 
and program relevant, effective, likely sustainable, and substantial in impact.7 It has, however, 
identified implementation delays as a common issue, ascribing them to EDC’s limited capacity 
in  (i) finalizing  detailed  technical  designs,  (ii)  handling  procurement,  and  (iii)  implementing 
safeguard measures in a timely manner. Such risks are mitigated under the project through 
(i) adopting  a  single  engineering,  procurement,  and  construction  (EPC)  package;  (ii)  EPC 
bidding documents already prepared during due diligence; and (iii) engaging consultants to 
support EDC to implement safeguard compliance measures during implementation. 
  
13.  The proposed project will continue ADB’s successful engagement in Cambodia’s energy 
sector. The project is not included in the country operations business plan, 2011–2013,8 but was 
processed based on urgent requests by the governments of Australia and Cambodia. It is fully 
aligned with the National Strategic Development Plan Update, 2009–2013 of the government, 
which calls for development of the energy sector through expansion of the electricity network to 
achieve the overarching objective of reducing poverty from 30.1% in 2008 to 19.5% by 2015. 
The project also corresponds to the objective of ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2011–2013 
of inclusive economic growth through the development of physical infrastructure such as power 
transmission, distribution, and rural electrification.9 The project is coherent with ADB’s energy 
sector assessment, strategy, and road map for Cambodia, which identify ADB’s focus in the 
sector  as  (i)  legal,  regulatory,  and  institutional  reform;  (ii)  rural  grid-electricity  supply 
infrastructure; and (iii) greater coordination with development partners.10  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact will be increased access to economical and reliable energy supply by the 
rural communities. The outcome will be the expanded supply of reliable grid electricity for up to 
8,000 households by December 2014, and sales of up to 90,000 NKS units benefiting at least 
63,000 women by December 2014. 
 
C.  Outputs 
15.  The project comprises three distinct components with the following outputs:  
(i)  Component  1:  Rural  electrification  of  Svay  Rieng  province.  A  total  of 
220 circuit-kilometers (cct-km) of medium-voltage lines and 400 cct-km of low-
voltage lines with meters will be energized in Svay Rieng province by September 
2014.  
(ii)  Component  2:  Promotion  of  Neang  Kongrey  Stove  in  Kampong  Cham 
province. At least 12 traditional cookstove producers will produce the NKS in 
Kampong Cham province by November 2014. A nongovernment organization 
(NGO)  with  experience  in  NKS  promotion  in  Cambodia—Groupe  Energies 
Renouvelables,  Environnement  et  Solidarités  (GERES)—will  be  recruited  to 
promote the NKS through technology transfer, provision of basic equipment to

are typically women, so that use of the NKS will become self-sustaining.  
(iii)  Component  3:  Capacity  development  of  the  Electricity  Authority  of 
Cambodia. Up to 20 EAC staff members will be trained in programs of the East 
Asia and Pacific Infrastructure Regulatory Forum (EAPIRF)11 and the Association 
of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  Energy  Regulators  Network  (AERN), 12 and  in 
targeted workshops, of which at least 15% of the participants are to be women.  
 
16.  The outcome of component 1 will be verified through an impact assessment, which 
includes a baseline survey. It will assess the impact on the beneficiaries’ livelihoods, including 
specific gender and health benefits. The outcome of component 2 will be verified through a 
separate baseline survey and impact assessment included in the terms of reference of GERES.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
1.  Component 1 
21.  Technology. The medium-voltage and low-voltage lines and equipment for Svay Rieng 
rural  electrification  use  standard  technologies,  and  technical  risks  are  low  as  EDC  has 
experience with developing and maintaining similar systems. 
 
22.  Location. Only 13,460 customers15 receive EDC service in Svay Rieng province, and 
about 2,000 customers are being supplied by three REEs.16 With 110,000 households in the 
province, the overall electrification rate is 14%.17 The existing Svay Rieng grid was partially 
developed by an ADB project.18 
 
23.  Source of power. EDC’s isolated network in Svay Rieng is supplied solely through 
import from Viet Nam. The power purchase of 17 MW is being negotiated to increase to 23 MW, 
which is sufficient to service the additional connections envisaged under the project. The import 
power tariff is $0.0835/kWh.19 
 
24.  Affordability. The social survey revealed that about 88% of the targeted unelectrified 
households rely on automobile batteries that cost $0.48 to charge every few days,20 and spend 
on average $2.1 per month on electricity. The unit cost of electricity from batteries, calculated to 
be about $1/kWh, is six times higher than the EDC tariff of $0.16/kWh in Svay Rieng. Therefore, 
once grid-connected, the households will be able to consume six times more electricity for the 
same expenditure. In addition, since it typically costs $50 every year to replace the batteries, the 
initial connection cost of about $60–$70 is judged to be affordable, especially since EDC’s initial 
connection fee can be repaid in installments over a 6-month period.  
 
2.  Component 2 
25.  Technology. The NKS has been developed by GERES to meet the needs of rural 
households in Cambodia. It builds on the earlier success of the New Lao Stove, also developed 
by GERES for use by urban households, which has sold over 1 million units since 2003.21 The 
NKS has been tested in neighboring Kampong Chhnang province, and has been recognized by

26.  Implementation.  GERES  is  an  NGO  with  a  strong  track  record  in  promoting  the 
improved cookstoves in Cambodia. GERES will train manufacturers of traditional cookstoves in 
Kampong Cham province to produce the NKS and ensure quality control, while conducting 
awareness campaigns to promote the NKS to distributors and consumers. 
 
27.  Location. This project component will have a high impact in Kampong Cham province 
since it has the highest rural population with the highest number of traditional cookstoves sold in 
recent years. The province also has the second highest poverty index in the country and one of 
the lowest forest coverage rates because of deforestation.23 
 
28.  Affordability. The retail price of the NKS at $1.25 is about the same as traditional ones, 
and has a similar, if not longer, service life of up to 18 months. 
 
3.  Component 3 
29.  The EAPIRF and AERN are networks for regulators, with the objective to improve public 
services regulatory capacity. The EAPIRF is supported by the World Bank and the Government 
of  Australia,  and  AERN  is  supported  by  ADB.  EAC  staff  will  learn  about  best  regulatory 
practices  in the forums  and  receive  customized  programs from resource  persons  on tariff 
methodology and regulatory reforms appropriate for Cambodia in the targeted workshops. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial  
30.  A financial analysis has been carried out for component 1 in accordance with ADB’s 
Financial Management and Analysis of Projects.24 All financial costs and benefits have been 
expressed at constant 2011 prices. Cost streams used to determine the financial internal rate of 
return—capital investment, and operation and maintenance—reflect the cost of delivering the 
estimated benefits. The financial internal rate of return of 4.74% compares favorably against the 
weighted average cost of capital of 4.28%.  
 
31.  The economic viability takes into account streams of costs and benefits resulting from 
the project. The economic internal rate of return is 17.58%, which compares favorably against 
the 12% opportunity cost of capital.

conducted  for  EDC  in  accordance  with  ADB  guidelines,  concluded  that  the  financial

auditors  as  independent  external  auditors  to  conduct  annual  audits  in  accordance  with 
international auditing standards. 
 
34.  The procurement capacity assessment states that EDC has a reasonable understanding 
of  ADB’s  guidelines  on  procurement  and  consultant  recruitment.  EDC  established  a 
procurement department in June 2011 to centralize procurement, which used to be performed 
by  the  various  project  management  offices.  The  procurement  department  director  has  a 
financial  background  whereas  most  staff  members  have  been  appointed  from  the  project 
management offices. EDC has also established a bid evaluation committee and a consultant 
selection committee, each chaired by the procurement department director and attended by 
MIME and the Ministry of Finance. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
35.  In rural Cambodia, the poverty rate is 35%26 and the electrification rate is about 11%. 
The majority of rural households, which are predominantly poor, rely on candles or charged 
automobile batteries for light and fuelwood for cooking. The reliable and economical electricity 
supplied  through  component  1  will  replace  expensive  batteries  and  reduce  household 
expenditure on energy. The improved efficiency of the cookstoves to be promoted through 
component 2 will reduce the risk of adverse health impacts of household pollution on women 
and children, as well as reduce the drudgery of fuelwood collection typically performed by them. 
 
36.  Key gender issues addressed by the project include (i) the affordability of connection 
fees that prevent access to energy, especially for low-income households headed by women; 
(ii) the high economic and health costs associated with using biomass sources of energy; and 
(iii) the  lack  of  women’s  engagement  in  the  energy  sector,  particularly  in  the  design  and 
dissemination of efficient cooking technologies. Under component 1, the gender action plan will 
ensure that a staggered installment payment modality for paying EDC’s initial connection fees is 
disseminated to the poor (including households headed by women) to access grid electricity. 
Under component 2, the gender action plan will ensure that (i) 63,000 women (including poor 
households and households headed by women) have access to the NKS; (ii) 100% of women 
entrepreneurs of cookstove-producing enterprises are mobilized to venture into NKS production; 
(iii) any new employment opportunities within the local stove producers target at least 50% local 
women;  (iv)  100%  of  women  retailers  in  the  targeted  areas  are  provided  with  awareness 
programs to understand the various benefits of the NKS; (v) 50% of the NGO facilitators are 
women;  (vi)  100%  of  relevant  women  MIME  staff  are  trained  on  the  NKS  technology; 
(vii) education activities are undertaken to increase women’s awareness of the health impacts of 
household pollution; and for component 3 (viii) at least 15% of EAC staff participating in the 
forums and training programs are women. The baseline details are provided in the gender 
action plan.27 
 
                                                
26 Government of Cambodia, Ministry of Planning. 2011. Achieving Cambodia’s Millennium Development Goals—
Update 2010. Phnom Penh. 
27 Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
E.  Safeguards 
37.  Environment (category B). The only expected adverse environmental impact of the 
project is the occupational and community health and safety during construction of the medium-
voltage and low-voltage lines under component 1. An initial environmental examination with an 
environmental  management  plan  has  been  prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009) and disclosed on ADB’s website on 12 July 2012. An environmental 
safeguard  expert  will  be  recruited  under  the  project  to  monitor  the  implementation  of  the 
environmental  management  plan.  The  expert  will  also  deliver  training  workshops  on 
environmental management as well as occupational and community health and safety.  
 
38.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). Adverse social impact is limited to the potential 
cutting of some trees for the stringing of the medium-voltage and low-voltage lines. Since the 
medium-voltage and low-voltage lines are to be installed within the existing right-of-way of the 
rural roads, the impact is minimal. A resettlement plan has been prepared in accordance with 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement.28 As the exact location of the medium-voltage and low-
voltage  poles  can  only  be  identified  during  detailed  design  by  the  EPC  contractor,  the 
resettlement plan will be updated by the EPC contractor. The contract will explicitly state that 
the resettlement plan must be updated by the EPC contractor, endorsed by EDC’s project 
management office 1, and submitted to ADB for approval. On-site installation works shall not 
commence for a given section until the approved resettlement plan is fully implemented. 
 
39.  Indigenous  peoples  (category  C). Due diligence has confirmed that there are no 
indigenous  peoples  in  the  project  area  following  the  identifying  characteristics  in  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
40.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 while other perceivable 
risks are described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.29

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
41.  The government, EDC, MIME, and EAC have assured ADB that implementation of the 
project shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the project administration manual and grant documents. 
 
42.  The government, EDC, MIME, and EAC have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for 
the project, which are set forth in the grant agreement and project agreement.  
 
43.  As a condition for disbursement of grant proceeds for component 1, (i) a subsidiary grant 
agreement, in a form and substance satisfactory to ADB, will be duly executed and delivered on 
behalf of the government and EDC; and (ii) EDC will have budgeted at least $2.80 million for 
component 1.  
 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
44.  I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the administration by 
ADB of the grant not exceeding the equivalent of $6,110,000 to the Kingdom of Cambodia for 
the Rural Energy Project, to be provided by the Government of Australia.
